awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Constraints of biomass on innate immunity across terrestrial mammals
awd_abstract_narration:
This project addresses two long-standing questions in biology, how genomes become phenomes and how organisms maintain stability through change, by investigating how body size affects immune defenses in terrestrial mammals. Although body mass is one of the strongest influences on many physiological traits, effects of body size are not known for immune systems. Through an unprecedented comparative approach, the research tests whether body size explains why some species are more susceptible to parasites and more likely to act as parasite reservoirs, whereas other species are resistant. Specifically, the research will provide new information on how functional forms of innate immunity relate to body size among >150 zoo-housed terrestrial mammal species spanning a broad range of sizes. Results will provide a framework for understanding of mammalian immune variation has the potential to enhance models of disease spread by providing predictions about the level of immune defense expected in species never before studied. The project fosters career development for two young investigators, a postdoctoral researcher, and 8-10 undergraduate research students. Participants will develop outreach activities for zoos and for biology classes at local middle and high schools, to enhance the educational effectiveness of zoo exhibits and lesson plans. These activities will demonstrate how comparative research is relevant to understanding human and animal health.

This project investigates whether and how body mass is related to the architecture of antimicrobial immune defenses in terrestrial mammals, an unstudied aspect of size-scaling. Host size likely affects i) the chance of exposure to infectious organisms, ii) the ability of immune defenses to keep pace with pathogen replication, iii) the ability of host surveillance mechanisms to detect threats in a comparatively large risk space. The project will determine how functional forms of innate immunity relate to body size among >150 zoo-housed species of terrestrial mammals spanning 7 orders of magnitude in body mass. In addition, protein expression for innate immune defenses as a function of body mass among 10 primate species spanning 5 orders of magnitude in size will be quantified. Using zoo-housed animals, which experience similar developmental histories in common environments, minimizes effects of confounding variables inherent to the study of wild individuals. Measuring functional antimicrobial responses is preferable to less direct assays of host defense. The transcriptomic methods will show which innate immune genes, gene networks, and/or gene modules are most sensitive to body mass. This project addresses two Grand Challenges in Organismal Biology, and has the potential to transform how scientists think about host-parasite interactions. The transcriptomic data generated will contribute to other systems biology pursuits, including understanding how size may constrain the evolution of regulatory processes in vertebrate animals. The participants, including 8-10 undergraduates, will develop interpretive displays and exhibits for zoos, and lesson plans for middle- and high-school biology classes to engage and educate students and the public and to demonstrate the relevance of comparative research.

por.por_cntn:
Why are some species more likely to act as reservoirs for parasites, whereas others are resistant? We explored the role of body size as a driver of variation in immune defense among vertebrate species. We suspected that body size would dramatically affect immune defenses because size affects i) the chance of exposure to infectious organisms, ii) the ability of immune defenses to keep pace with pathogen replication, and iii) the ability of hosts to detect threats in a comparatively large risk space. We found that large mammals and birds circulated disproportionately more early acting, antimicrobial cells (neutrophils and heterophils) than their small counterparts.  This discovery led to what we called the Safety Factor Hypothesis, which proposes generlly that large organisms need greater early and broadly acting defenses. This pattern for birds was detectable regardless of whether samples came from wild or captive animals, suggesting that scaling relationships between size and some immune defenses are consistent no matter the context in which they are measured.

Cell counts are a morphological measure of immunity and do not tell us about the functional capacity of defenses, so we also described the ability of circulating concentrations of sera-based immune components to kill and halt the growth of three different species of bacteria. Surprisingly, this functional immune response scaled proportionately with body mass in >160 species of mammals. This relationship is greater than we'd expect based on metabolic rate variation among species, given that cellular metabolism, a process proposed to regulate rates of biological processes, decreases disproportionately with body mass. We concluded that large animals do indeed protect themselves from infection disproportionately, as predictedby the Safety Factor Hypothesis, because this functional defense was greater than expected given metabolic rates.

We also queried the effects of body size of several species of primates on innate immune regulatory architecture of the blood of each species. We made two significant findings after we induced simulated bacterial infections in live blood samples of primate then measured subsequent gene expression. First, we found that innate immune genes had higher priority than other genes; innate immune genes were over- or -underexpressed to a much greater degree than other genes in large than small species. Second, we found that large primate species expressed substantially more innate immune genes than would be expected from their size alone, again supporting the Safety Factor hypothesis.

Our research also contributed to five broader impact activities. First, we shared our results widely with a scientific audience through scientific presentations and publications. Second, we developed two peer-reviewed case studies on the immune system available to educators through the National Center for Case Study Teaching in Science. Third, students in one principal investigator's animal physiology course made eight displays about how basic science research informs human and animal health that comprised a temporary exhibit at the Museum of Science and Technology in Syracuse, NY. This museum has an annual visitation of ~100,000, and all 2nd-, 5th-, and 8th-grade students from the diverse Syracuse City School District visit the museum as part of their curriculum each year. This activity fostered cross-disciplinaryeducation in science communication for the 30 biology majors who participated. Fourth, undergraduate students at Hamilton College developed lesson plans about how conservation is related to human health,which were disseminated to our 23 zoo partners. These students also created a permanent display on Lymedisease and conservation for the Utica Zoo in Utica, NY. Finally, this grant trained >23 undergraduate researchers, a Master's student, two post-doctoral researchers, and a research associate (many from groups underrepresented in science fields) while launching the career of a female, early-career researcher.
